awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT:  Surgical Robotic System for Long Bone Fracture Alignment
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project is to greatly reduce malalignments and associated complications from femoral (thigh bone) fracture surgery. More than half of all fractures occur in long bones like the femur. In the United States, 430,000 femur fractures occur annually; and globally, motor vehicle accidents cause an estimated 1-3 million femoral shaft fractures each year.  Surgery to manually align long bones is arduous and difficult due to the bone’s elongated anatomy and the opposing strength of the surrounding muscles, requiring the surgeon and medical staff to exert high traction forces during the procedure.  Poor alignment of the bone fragments is a potentially serious complication, and one-third of patients experiencing this require additional corrective surgery that increases costs and more complications. The proposed robot reduces healthcare costs by eliminating repeated operations and decreasing procedure times. This benefits patients, surgeons, and hospitals by improving patient outcomes and reduces the cost of care. 

The proposed project develops an orthopedic surgical robotic system for long-bone fracture surgeries. A malrotation of 15° or more occurs in 28% of patients. Malalignment leads to leg-length discrepancies and abnormal gait. The proposed concept consists of a surgical robot, bone-gripping system, and force-feedback controller to manipulate the robot. This enables the surgeon to accurately apply large traction forces and precisely align the fractured bone. The proposed architecture consists of a 3-armed manipulator with two wide-open rings; it facilitates positioning the leg inside the robot, providing a large workspace for surgical maneuvers.  The objectives are to: (1) optimize the design to provide highly accurate alignment of bone segments and (2) develop a force-feedback controller to accurately align bone segments, coupled with software to predict muscle forces. To achieve these objectives, the research will employ mechanical design optimization, analytical modeling, computation, experimentation, and testing on cadavers. The outcome will be a robotic platform that can be further integrated with image-guided path-planning algorithms for anatomic alignment of long-bone fractures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Approximately 430,000 femoral fractures occur annually in the United States, making the femur, the body’s longest bone, a frequent site of traumatic injury. Definitive management requires precise restoration of length and rotational alignment before stabilization with intramedullary hardware or plate‑screw constructs. This reduction is traditionally performed manually while the powerful thigh musculature exerts counteracting forces, and even in expert hands clinically significant malalignment is common: nearly one‑third of patients subsequently require revision surgery to correct limb shortening or malrotation.

Supported by the National Science Foundation, we have developed Robossis, a six‑degree‑of‑freedom robotic platform designed to augment the reduction phase of femoral fracture fixation. The device employs two concentric open rings that encircle the limb, providing unimpeded surgical access while delivering controlled, high‑magnitude traction. Three coordinated robotic arms, based on a patented architecture affording a rotational workspace fifteen‑fold greater than that of conventional Stewart platforms, allow fine manipulation of the fracture fragments. A haptic, force‑feedback interface conveys real‑time musculoskeletal resistance to the surgeon, enabling intuitive guidance without the physical burden inherent in manual traction.

Cadaveric validation demonstrated restoration of femoral length to within 0.5 mm and rotational alignment to within 2°, markedly surpassing accuracy achievable with current manual techniques. The robotic system also reduced the duration of the reduction step by approximately 40%, owing to its capacity to maintain constant traction autonomously. In post‑trial surveys, 90% of participating trauma surgeons indicated a willingness to adopt Robossis clinically, citing diminished operator fatigue and enhanced confidence in final alignment.

Achieving accurate alignment on the initial procedure obviates costly re‑operations, accelerates rehabilitation, and diminishes overall health‑care expenditures; each avoided revision saves an estimated $25,000–$45,000. For patients, this translates to improved gait mechanics and a lower incidence of chronic pain. Ongoing collaborations with industry leaders aim to refine the system for operating‑room deployment and to integrate advanced image‑guided planning algorithms. Moreover, the project has fostered the professional development of a graduate entrepreneur and successive cohorts of undergraduate engineers from diverse backgrounds, providing experiential training in medical‑device innovation and user‑centred design.

By synergising surgical expertise with robotic precision and strength, Robossis has the potential to render femoral fracture reduction safer, more efficient, and more accurate for hundreds of thousands of patients each year.

 


Last Modified: 04/18/2025
Modified by: Mohammad Abedin Nasab
